sections.title: SOURCES
sections.content_md: The southern part of the Indian peninsula, south of the Krishna river, was inhabited by the **Dravidians**, with powerful kingdoms like the **Cheras**, the **Pandyas**, and the **Cholas**. The Chola Empire arose in the ninth century, developing a powerful navy that enabled sea trade, and the conquest of Sri Lanka and the Maldive Islands. By the end of the 9th century, the Cholas defeated the Pallavas of Kanchi and weakened the Pandyans, bringing the Tamil country (**Tondamandala**) under their control.

sections.title: Inscriptions
sections.content_md:
The main source of information for the history of the Chola period is the large number of inscriptions. **Rajaraja I** conceived the idea of prefixing his main achievements to his inscriptions, a practice followed by his successors.

[Image: Copper-plate Inscriptions]

**Forms of Inscriptions:**
*   **Copper-plate grants:** Examples include the **Anbil** and **Karandi** grants. Another set contains 31 copper sheets in Sanskrit and Tamil, recording a grant to a temple by **Rajendra Chola I**.
*   **Stone inscriptions:** The **Kanyakumari** stone inscription provides a long list of rulers.
*   **Inscriptions on temple walls and pillars.**

**Information from Inscriptions:**
1.  **Chola administration:** The **Uttaramerur inscription** gives information on village administration, taxation, and land revenue.
2.  **Gifts and endowments:** They record gifts to temples and brahmanas. Copper-plate inscriptions are records of grants of villages, land, or other privileges. The **Leyden grant** of Parantaka Chola is an example.
3.  **Temple construction:** They inform about the construction of a temple or the setting up of a new image of a deity.
4.  **Royal orders and judgements:** Some inscriptions contain royal orders on taxation, resolutions of village assemblies, and judgements against criminals.
5.  **Public registrations:** Inscriptions on temple walls served as records of sales, mortgages, and other property transfers in village lands.

sections.title: The Brihadeshwara temple
sections.content_md:
The Cholas built numerous temples with key features like a gateway (**gopuram**), the main shrine (**garbhagriha**), and an audience hall (**mandapa**). Chola temples are characterized by their massive **vimanas** (towers) and spacious courtyards.

[Image: Brihadeshwara Temple]

The best example of a Chola temple is the **Brihadeshwara temple**, also known as **Rajarajeshwara temple**, at **Thanjavur**. It was built by **Rajaraja I** and is dedicated to Lord Shiva. It is a prime specimen of the Dravidian style of architecture and a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

**Key Architectural Features:**
*   A great **vimana** rising to a height of 66 metres.
*   It is crowned by a massive dome made from a single block of stone, weighing about 80 tons.
*   The temple is built of 130,000 tons of granite and is covered with sculptures and decorative mouldings.
*   The shrine houses a gigantic **Shiva Lingam**, cut from a monolithic rock, about 8.87 metres high.
*   It includes structures like a **Nandi Pavilion**, a pillared portico, and a large assembly hall.

sections.title: The temple has a portrait of Rajaraja Chola paying obeisance to Lord Nataraja.
sections.content_md: The temple has a portrait of Rajaraja Chola paying obeisance to Lord Nataraja. This is the first known instance of a royal portrait.

sections.title: Inscriptions in the temple point towards Rajaraja as the chief architect of the temple.
sections.content_md: Inscriptions in the temple point towards Rajaraja as the chief architect of the temple.

sections.title: Depictions of dancers showing eighty one of hundred and eight karanas
sections.content_md: Depictions of dancers showing eighty one of hundred and eight **karanas** (synchronised movements of hands and feet) in **Bharata Natyam** are carved in the temple. This shows that the temple was a platform for talented dancers, and these depictions are the first of their kind.

sections.title: The inscriptions mention the different kinds of jewels used in the Chola period.
sections.content_md: The inscriptions mention different kinds of jewels used in the Chola period. A total of twenty-three different types of pearls, eleven varieties of diamonds, and rubies are mentioned.

sections.title: It is one of the few temples that have Ashta-dikpaalakas
sections.content_md: It is one of the few temples that have **Ashta-dikpaalakas** (Guardians of the eight directions) idols.

sections.title: POLITICAL HISTORY
sections.content_md: Chola ruler **Vijayalaya** established Chola rule in Tamil land in the mid-ninth century, with **Thanjavur** as his capital. His grandson, **Parantaka I**, conquered Madurai and defeated the Pandyas and rulers of Lanka. By the 11th century AD, Chola power reached its peak under **Rajaraja I** and his son, **Rajendra Chola**.

sections.title: Rajaraja I
sections.content_md:
**Rajaraja I** was a brilliant general who campaigned extensively.
*   He attacked the kingdoms of the **Pandyas** and the **Cheras**, as well as parts of **Mysore**.
*   He annexed parts of **Deccan**, overran **Vengi**, and took territories in **Mysore**, **Travancore**, and **Coorg**.
*   Recognizing the importance of sea control for trade, he conducted a naval expedition, attacking and conquering the northern half of **Sri Lanka** and the **Maldive Islands**.
*   He built the **Rajarajeshwara temple** of Lord Shiva at Thanjavur, where his main achievements are inscribed.
*   Under his rule, the Cholas became the supreme power in Southern India. The increase in trade brought prosperity to their kingdom, **Cholamandal** (from which the word Coromandel is derived).

sections.title: Rajendra Chola
sections.content_md:
**Rajendra Chola** succeeded his father, Rajaraja I, and continued his policies.
*   He invaded and annexed the entire island of Sri Lanka, which remained under Chola control for another 50 years.
*   His armies marched up the east coast of India, through Odisha, to the **Ganga river**. The Chola army defeated **Mahipala**, the king of Bengal.
*   To commemorate this victory, he adopted the title of **Gangaikonda** and built a new capital called **Gangaikonda-Cholapuram** in present-day Tamil Nadu.
*   His most daring campaign was in South-East Asia. Indian merchants trading through the Straits of Malacca faced problems from the kingdom of **Shrivijaya** (modern Indonesia). At their request, Rajendra Chola sent a large navy, defeated the Shrivijaya king, and secured Indian trade with South-East Asia and southern China, greatly enriching the Chola kingdom.

[Image: Vimana of Brihadeshwara Temple]

sections.title: THE CHOLA ADMINISTRATION
sections.content_md: The Chola system of administration was highly organised and efficient. The king was the pivot of the administration, holding all authority.

sections.title: Central Government
sections.content_md:
*   The **king** was the most important person, advised by a **Council of Ministers**.
*   The king often went on tours to check on the administration.
*   Officers were paid through assignments in revenue-bearing lands.
*   Princes were associated with the ruling sovereigns and were actively employed in peace and war.
*   The central government managed external defence, internal peace and order, and promoted the general prosperity and cultural progress of the empire.

sections.title: Provincial Government
sections.content_md: The Chola empire was divided into **mandalams** (provinces), which were further divided into **valanadu** and **nadu**. Princes of the royal family were appointed as governors of provinces.

sections.title: Local Self-Government
sections.content_md:
The Cholas believed in **local self-government**, and in many villages, administration was carried out by the villagers themselves. There were three types of village assemblies:
*   **The ur:** A common assembly in villages where land was held by all classes of people.
*   **The sabha:** An exclusively Brahmin assembly in villages where all land belonged to Brahmins.
*   **The nagaram:** An assembly of merchants in localities where traders were dominant.

Villagers who owned land were chosen by a vote to the council. These councils discussed the life and work of the villages. All affairs concerning the village, such as tax collection, dispute settlement, and water allocation, were handled by these committees.

**Role of Temples in Administration and Society:**
*   The temple was the center of social activity.
*   Some temples owned huge lands (**devadaya** or **devadana**) and participated in trade.
*   Land revenue of some villages was assigned to temples, making them major employers.
*   Temples cared for their workers by providing food, clothing, housing, education, and hospitals.
*   The temple was also a centre for education, with priests acting as local teachers. Schools were housed in the temple courtyard, and students learned in **Sanskrit** and **Tamil**.

sections.title: The Revenue
sections.content_md:
The revenue of the Chola kingdom came from:
*   Taxes on land and the produce of the land.
*   Tax on trade.

A portion of the revenue was kept for the king. The rest was used for public works (building roads and tanks), salaries of officials, army upkeep, and building temples. Taxes on land were collected by officials from the village councils.

sections.title: The Chola Art
sections.content_md:
The Chola rulers were great conquerors and efficient administrators who loved art and architecture. They built temples, canals, roads, cities, and palaces, mostly in the **Dravidian style**. Early Chola temples were simple, but later ones became bigger and more grand.

The art of making stone and metal images progressed rapidly. The Cholas excelled in creating images of gods and goddesses. The bronze image of Lord Shiva as **‘Nataraja’—Lord of Dance**, is an excellent work of art and has been described as the “cultural epitome” of the Chola period.

[Image: Nataraja]
